profileText: A Senator from Idaho; born in Mount Pleasant, Sanpete County, Utah, May 15, 1899; educated in the public schools of Enterprise, Oreg.; enlisted in the United States Army during the First World War; graduated from University of Oregon in 1923; farmer, rancher, businessman, and economic adviser; director of Circle C Ranch and of the Jordan Motor Co.; resident of Grangeville, Idaho, 1941-1951; member, State legislature 1947-1949; Governor of Idaho 1951-1955; chairman, International Joint Commission 1955-1957; member, International Development Advisory Board 1958-1959; appointed on August 6, 1962, as a Republican to the United States Senate to fill the vacancy caused by the death of Henry C. Dworshak; elected November 6, 1962, for remainder of term, ending January 3, 1967; reelected in 1966 and served from August 6, 1962, to January 2, 1973; was not a candidate for reelection in 1972; was a resident of Boise, Idaho, until his death there June 30, 1983; interment in Cloverdale Cemetery.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Jordan, Grace E. The Unintentional Senator. Boise: Syms-York Co., 1972.

researchRecord.name: 1971. 8 pages. Limited to reminiscences of Russell.

recordLocation.name: Richard B. Russell Library for Political Research and Studies

researchRecord.name: 1962-1972. 250 feet. Correspondence, speeches, press releases, legislative files, case files, subject files, campaign material, voting records, and photographs documenting service in U.S. Senate. Includes material relating to Bonneville Power Administration, service on Interior and Insular Affairs committee, his 1966 campaign, and agriculture, natural resources, water projects, reclamation, public lands issues and Idaho politics. Finding aid. Case files restricted.
